description: From Middle English wryngen, wringen, from Old English wringan, from Proto-Germanic *wringaną, from Proto-Indo-European *wrenǵʰ-.

See also West Frisian wringe, Low German wringen, Dutch wringen, German ringen (“to wrestle”); also Lithuanian reñgtis (“to bend down”), Ancient Greek ῥίμφα (rhímpha, “fast”), nasalized variant of *werǵʰ- ‘bind, squeeze’. More at worry.

entries.meaning: A powerful squeezing or twisting action.
examples: I grasped his hand and gave it a grateful wring.
When we have good dayes we slight them, when they are gone, we sinke under the wring of sorrow, for their losse;

verbs.description: wring (third-person singular simple present wrings, present participle wringing, simple past wrung or wrang or (rare) wringed, past participle wrung or (rare) wringed)

entries.meaning: To squeeze or twist (something) tightly so that liquid is forced out. See also wring out.
examples: I didn’t have a towel so I just wrung my hair dry.

entries.meaning: To extract (a liquid) from something wet, especially cloth, by squeezing and twisting it.
examples: Put the berries into a cheesecloth and wring the juice into a bowl.

entries.meaning: To obtain (something from or out of someone or something) by force.
examples: The police said they would wring the truth out of that heinous criminal.

entries.meaning: To draw (something from or out of someone); to generate (something) as a response.
To hold (something) tightly and press or twist.
examples: to wring one's hands (with worry, etc.)
to wring someone's hand (i.e. shake hands with someone)
to wring someone's / an animal's neck

entries.meaning: To cause pain or distress to (someone / one's heart, soul, etc.).
To slide two ultraflat surfaces together such that their faces bond.
examples: The surface finish of the ceramic platen appears very similar to that of the gauge  block by eye . The pack experiment method to evaluate phase correction is  valuable in that the differences associated with wringing two different materials  and ...

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To twist, as if in pain.
(obsolete) To give an incorrect meaning to (words, teachings, etc.).
(obsolete) To subject (someone) to extortion; to afflict or oppress in order to enforce compliance.
(nautical) To bend or strain out of its position.

description: From Middle English wrynge (“press”), from Old English wringe.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A device for pressing or compressing, especially for cider.
